sections.content: What if you could save $50, $100, or even $200 a month — without changing anything about your lifestyle? No cutting back on groceries. No skipping the kids' activities. Just picking up the phone and asking. That's the power of negotiating your bills, and it's one of the most underused money moves out there.
WHY COMPANIES WANT TO KEEP YOU

Here's something most people don't realise: it costs companies 5-10 times more to get a new customer than to keep an existing one. Your phone company, your internet provider, your insurance company — they would rather give you a discount than lose you. That's your leverage.

The average Australian family spends over $200/month on phone and internet alone. Studies show that people who call and negotiate save an average of $30-$50 per bill. That's $360-$600 a year — from a few phone calls.

Not every bill is negotiable, but these almost always are:

- Mobile phone plan: Providers have unadvertised plans and loyalty deals. Always ask.
- Internet/broadband: Especially if you've been on the same plan for over a year.
- Car insurance: Get a quote from a competitor, then call your current provider.
- Home & contents insurance: Same strategy — a competing quote is your best weapon.
- Health insurance: Ask about lower tiers, excess adjustments, or loyalty discounts.
- Electricity & gas: Compare plans on government comparison sites, then call to switch or negotiate.
- Gym memberships: Especially if you're not using it much. They'd rather drop the price than lose you.
- Subscription services: Even streaming services sometimes offer discounted rates if you say you're thinking of cancelling.

You don't need to be a tough negotiator. You just need to be polite, prepared, and willing to ask. Here are scripts you can read straight from your phone:

SCRIPT 1 — Mobile / Internet:
"Hi, I've been a customer for [X months/years] and I'm reviewing my household budget. I've seen that [Competitor] is offering a similar plan for $[amount]. I'd really like to stay with you — is there anything you can do to match that or offer me a better deal?"

SCRIPT 2 — Insurance:
"Hi, my renewal has come through at $[amount] and it's quite a bit more than I was expecting. I've got a quote from [Competitor] for $[lower amount]. Can you review my policy and see if there's a way to bring the price down? I've been happy with your service and would prefer to stay."

SCRIPT 3 — If they say no:
"I understand. Could you transfer me to your retentions or cancellations team? I'd like to explore my options before I make a decision."

The retentions team almost always has better deals. That's their whole job — keeping you.

Top tips for your calls:

- Call on a Tuesday or Wednesday morning. Wait times are shorter and staff are less rushed.
- Have your current bill in front of you so you can reference exact amounts.
- Be friendly. The person on the phone is a real human — kindness goes a long way.
- Write down the name of who you spoke to and what was agreed.
- If you have kids making noise in the background, don't stress. It happens. The person on the phone gets it.
- Set a calendar reminder to call again in 12 months. Deals expire and prices creep up.

sections.content:
Real mum results:

- "I called my phone company and got $15/month off just by asking. That's $180 a year!" — Jess, mum of one
- "Switched car insurance after getting a competitor quote. Saved $400 on my annual premium." — Mei, mum of three
- "I was paying $89/month for internet. Called and said I was thinking of leaving. They dropped it to $65 on the spot." — Sam, mum of two

These aren't extraordinary stories. This is what happens when you simply ask.

Companies would rather give you a discount than lose you. A few polite phone calls using simple scripts can save you hundreds of dollars a year. Get a competitor quote, call your provider, ask for a better deal, and request the retentions team if they say no.

You negotiate for your kids every single day — with teachers, with doctors, at the school gate. You already have the skills. Now it's time to use them for your wallet. One phone call at a time, you're putting real money back in your pocket. Go get those savings, mama.
